journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Robust control of conjugated polymer actuators considering the spatio-temporal dynamics

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Kashan, Islamic Republic of Iran
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Islamic Republic of Iran

author-notes.corresp: Amir Ali Amiri Moghadam, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, PO Box 9177948944-11, Mashhad, Islamic Republic of Iran. Email: am_am302@stu-mail.um.ac.ir

abstract.p: Conjugated polymers are emerging materials which have a wide range of applications including biomimetic robots and biomedical devices. These novel materials attract considerable attention owing to their interesting sensing and actuating behavior. However, complicated electro-chemo-mechanical dynamics is a drawback for their application in functional devices. Although extensive research has been conducted on static modeling of conductive polymers, the dynamic modeling is not well understood. In this paper we focus on dynamic modeling and robust control of a fast trilayer polypyrrole actuator as a distributed parameter system. The Euler–Bernoulli beam model with inclusion of Kelvin–Voigt damping and tip loading is utilized for vibration analysis of the smart actuator. Considering the spatio-temporal dynamics of the actuator, a one-point feedback controller based on quantitative feedback theory is designed that can suppress arbitrary external disturbances and consistently track desired inputs.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is an increasing need for a new generation of actuators that can be used in devices such as artificial organs, micro robots, human-like robots, and medical applications. Up to now many research studies have been undertaken on developing new actuators such as shape memory alloys, piezoelectric actuators, magnetostrictive actuators, contractile polymer actuators, and electrostatic actuators.1,2 The main disadvantages of these actuators are low efficiency, high electrical power, and low strain generation.2 Electroactive polymers (EAPs) seem to be among the best possible candidates for application in micromanipulation systems since they produce reasonable strain under low input voltage. EAPs are a relatively new class of materials which can be used as both sensor and actuator.3 Conductive polymers (CPs) and ionic metal–polymer composites (IPMCs) are among the EAP materials which exhibit interesting sensing and actuating behavior.4 There are many reports in the literature about the potential application of EAPs in different robotic systems. Chen et al. reported the modeling of a robotic fish propelled by an IPMC actuator.5 Bar-Cohen et al. presented several EAP-driven mechanisms that emulate the human hand including a gripper, manipulator arm, and surface wiper.6 Jager et al. reviewed the current status of micro actuators based on EAPs. They described micro fabrication of these actuators plus their possible application in micro systems.7 Moghadam et al. have proposed the application of an adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system in kinematic modeling of a soft micro robot based on conjugated polymer actuators.8

The main process that is responsible for volumetric change and the resultant actuation ability of conjugated polymer actuators is reduction/oxidation (redox). Thus based on different fabrication forms, different configurations of the actuators can be obtained, namely linear extenders, bilayer benders, and trilayer benders.9–11 By applying a voltage to the actuator, the polypyrrole (PPy) layer on the anode side is oxidized while that on the cathode side is reduced. Ions can transfer inside the conjugated polymer actuator by two main mechanisms, namely diffusion and drift.12 The trilayer PPy actuator, which could operate both in air and liquid environments, is a promising material for application in micromanipulation systems.13,14 Before such an actuator can be utilized in practical applications, it is essential to understand its dynamics. Especially in applying the fast trilayer PPy actuator, we must take into account the proper mechanical dynamics. Most of the models available in the literature of CP actuators have focused on static operating conditions;9,15,16 however, the application of these materials in practical devices requires a dynamic modeling approach. Although Fang et al.17 proposed a dynamic model for trilayer polymer actuators, they only used an electrical admittance model of the actuator and ignored the mechanical dynamics. The main contributions for modeling the mechanical dynamics of the fast trilayer PPy actuator are mainly limited to presenting and evaluating the experimental data.13,14,18,19 In our previous work we applied the finite element method for modeling of polymer actuators.20 In this paper we develop a complete analytical dynamic model between the input voltage and output displacement for the fast trilayer PPy actuator.

As mentioned, the model of Fang et al.17 is based on the electrical admittance of the actuator; therefore it cannot predict the resonant frequencies or the effects of tip loading on the actuator’s dynamic behavior. With this in mind, in the present study we develop a complete electro-chemo-mechanical dynamic model by adding proper electro-mechanical dynamics to the previous model.17 The dynamic equation of the PPy actuator is derived on the basis of the Euler–Bernoulli model with the inclusion of Kelvin–Voigt damping and tip loading. Subsequently Galerkin’s method21,22 is utilized to approximate the dynamic equation by a finite set of ordinary differential equations. Our proposed modeling approaches are validated based on existing experimental data.19 This model can be used both to optimize the open-loop displacement of the actuator and to design a proper controller, which will lead to practical use of the actuator in micro/nano systems.

In contrast to CP actuators there are several contributions on the control of IPMC actuators. Mallavparu and Leo23 used the linear quadratic regulator (LQR) technique for control of IPMC actuators. Richardson et al.24 employed a proportional–integral–derivative (PID) controller for an IPMC film. Bhat and Kim25 designed a lag compensator for IPMC material. Kang et al.26 showed that robust control strategies have superior controlling performance over the conventional PID controller when applied to IPMC materials. Application of the H∞ control strategy was proposed by Yamakita et al.27 Brufau-Penella et al.28 developed an adaptive control technique for IPMC strips. Utilizing both sensing and actuation properties of IPMC materials, Hunt et al.29 designed a proportional–integral (PI) controller for a coupled IPMC sensor–actuator. Ahn et al.30 applied quantitative feedback theory (QFT) for position control of IPMC actuators.

The control of CP actuators is relatively unexplored. The application of a PID controller for a PPy actuator based on a first-order model was presented by Madden.31 PID and adaptive control approaches based on a first-order empirical model were reported by Bowers.32 The robust adaptive control approach was used by Fang et al.33 In our previous works, we have used several controlling approaches to control PPy actuators.34–36 The common property among all of the control strategies mentioned above is that they did not consider the dynamics of the actuator as a distributed parameter system (DPS). In the other words, the spatial distribution of the sensor, actuator, disturbances, and control objectives has not been considered in the design of the controller. With this in mind, the objective of the present study was to design a controller based on QFT which is robust against uncertainty in both the plant and the spatial distribution of the inputs and outputs.

The reminder of the paper is organized as follows. First, the classical admittance model of the actuator is briefly reviewed. Then suitable mechanical dynamics of the actuator is obtained. Finally, a robust controller based on QFT is designed for tracking and disturbance rejection problems.

sec.title: Trilayer polypyrrole actuator
sec.p: In this paper, as an example of the conjugated polymer actuators, the trilayer PPy actuator is considered. Figure 1 depicts the trilayer PPy actuator. As the name indicates, the trilayer PPy actuator consists of three layers: the middle layer comprises porous polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) which is used as a storage tank for the electrolyte, and on both sides there are polymer layers (PPy).14,37

caption.p: Three-layer PPy actuator.
PVDF: polyvinylidene fluoride; PPy: polypyrrole.

sec.p: As mentioned in the Introduction, the main process responsible for the volumetric change of conjugated polymer actuators is redox. Thus in the trilayer bender while the PPy layer on the anode side is oxidized and expands as a result, the PPy layer on the cathode side is reduced and contracts. Therefore this difference in volume leads to the bending of the actuator.

sec.title: Electro-chemo-mechanical modeling
sec.p: The electro-chemo-mechanical model is comprised of two parts, namely the electrochemical model and the electromechanical model.

sec.title: Electrochemical model
sec.p:
The electrochemical model relates the input voltage and the chemical redox reaction inside the PPy actuator. Figure 2 depicts the electrical admittance model. For a detailed description of the equations governing the electrochemical model, please refer to earlier works.17,20 The admittance model,
Y ( s ) = I ( s ) / V ( s )
, of a trilayer PPy actuator is
where the physical parameters of equation (1) are illustrated in Table 1.

caption.p: Description of diffusion and double-layer charging and its equivalent electrical circuit.
Definition of physical parameters.

sec.title: Electromechanical model
sec.p: The electromechanical model relates the input voltage and bending displacement of the PPy actuator. It was shown experimentally that the relationship between the induced in-plane strain ϵ and the density of the transferred charges ρ is given as31

where
α

is the strain-to-charge ratio. Thus, the induced stress is
where EPPy is the Young’s modulus of PPy, and ρ can be achieved in the Laplace domain as31

where W is the width of the PPy, hPPy is the thickness of the PPy, and L is the length of the PPy. Three-layer polymer actuators can bend because of the expansion of the top layer and contraction of the bottom layer. The stresses induced in expanded and contracted layers are assumed to be the same and in opposite directions. Distribution of the induced stress is approximately constant along the thickness. Additionally the application of gold layers on both sides of the PVDF layer diminishes the potential drop along the length of the actuator, thus the actuation process is analogous with the pure bending within the actuator. Based on Figure 3, one can obtain the bending moment as
where A is the actuator’s cross-sectional area. Thus the relationship between the input voltage V and the output bending moment MC is obtained as

caption.p: Stress distribution across the thickness of the trilayer polymer actuator.

sec.p: According to Figure 4 the actuation process within the trilayer PPy actuator can be modeled as an external moment. Based on the available experimental results19 for the range of actuator length from 2 to 25 mm, it can be seen that the magnitude of the actuator displacement is too small after the second natural resonant frequency, which can be considered a bandwidth limitation for a fast trilayer PPy actuator. With this in mind the Euler–Bernoulli beam model can be a proper choice for predicting the frequency-domain behavior of the actuator. However to predict the higher values of natural resonant frequencies one may use the Timoshenko beam model. Considering the effects of a point mass mt at the tip of the beam, the external disturbance fd, and the Kelvin–Voigt damping model, the governing equation of motion based on Euler–Bernoulli beam theory can be defined as

where δ(·) represents the Dirac delta function, η is the damping coefficient, EI is the equivalent flexural rigidity, and ρA is the product of density and cross-sectional area of the actuator. Moreover the boundary conditions are

caption.p: Consideration of the actuation process as an external moment.

sec.title: Solution of the problem by means of Galerkin’s method
sec.p: Equations (7) and (8) constitute a boundary value problem which defines the dynamic equation of the PPy actuator. Based on Galerkin’s method this problem can be approximated by a finite set of ordinary differential equations. Therefore, the normalized output displacement of the actuator can be approximated by Galerkin expansion as

In order to validate the proposed dynamic model, the available published experimental results19 are employed. This is done based on the experimental data of a 2 mm wide, 10 mm long, fast trilayer PPy bending actuator. Both time- and frequency-domain simulation results are presented in order to evaluate our proposed dynamic model. Figure 5 compares the simulated and experimental output displacement of the actuator in response to a step voltage input. It is evident that the model shows a relatively good match with experimental results. Figure 6 compares the bode plot of the experimental results reported by John19 with the response of our theoretical model, which indicates that the purposed model can predict the actuator’s frequency-domain behavior well. We have also considered the effects of tip mass variation which can be important in practical application of the actuator in functional devices. According to Figure 7 an increase of the tip mass will decrease the fundamental natural frequency, which is consistent with the reported experimental data.19

caption.p: Input voltage plus experimental and simulated output displacement response of a 2 mm wide, 10 mm long, fast trilayer PPy bending actuator.
Dynamic displacement response of a 2 mm wide, 10 mm long, fast trilayer PPy bending actuator.
Dynamic displacement response of a 2 mm wide, 10 mm long, fast trilayer PPy bending actuator with 0, 11.2, 22.3, and 35.5 mg tip masses.

sec.title: Application of quantitative feedback theory to distributed parameter systems
sec.p: There are many practical systems that have high uncertainty in open-loop transfer functions which makes it very difficult to have suitable stability margins and good performance in command-following problems for the closed-loop system. Therefore a single fixed controller in such systems is found among the family of “robust controllers”. QFT is a robust feedback control-system design technique, initially introduced by Horowitz38, which allows direct design to closed-loop robust performance and stability specifications. Since its introduction this technique has been developed by Horowitz and others.38–42 In many techniques from the “robust control” family such as H∞, design is based on the magnitude of the transfer function in the frequency domain; however QFT is concerned not only with this, but also is able to take into account phase information in the design process.43 The unique feature of QFT is that the performance specifications are expressed as bounds on frequency-response loop shapes in such a way that satisfaction of these bounds implies a corresponding approximate closed-loop satisfaction of some time-domain response bounds for given classes of inputs and for all uncertainty in a given compact set. Compared with lumped systems, the application of QFT for DPSs is still an open research area. However, most physical systems have a distributed nature. That means they have spatio-temporal dynamics and should be modeled by partial differential equations (PDEs). Horowitz and Azor44,45 proposed the first application of QFT to DPSs. Based on Horowitz’s work, Kelemen et al.46 developed a one-point feedback approach for DPSs. Extensions of the Nyquist stability criterion for distributed systems were presented by Chait et al.47 Garcia-Sanz et al.48 proposed a simple methodology to design QFT controllers for DPSs. They extended the classical QFT method by introducing new robust performance bounds which could take into account the spatial distribution of the system. This method is now described briefly.

Consider a DPS which can be described by means of linear PDE. Figure 8 shows the general feedback structure of a DPS. This system has a two-degree-of-freedom (2DOF) structure (consider controller G(s) and pre-filter F(s)), where xs, xa, xd, and xo represent the location of the sensor, the actuator, the disturbances, and the control objective respectively and H is the sensor. The dynamics of the DPS can be explained based on a set of transfer functions,

It is evident that the spatio-temporal dynamics of the DPS can be modeled with a set of transfer functions (TFs) which has a rational form.48 Therefore, the classical QFT method which has been developed based on rational TFs can be extended to deal with the DPS. Having this in mind Garcia-Sanz et al.48 introduced new robust performance bounds which describe the DPS feedback problem based on quadratic inequalities. It must be noted that the uncertainty in

sec.title: Design of QFT controller for fast trilayer polypyrrole actuator
sec.p: As shown in the section “Electro-chemo-mechanical modeling”, a fast trilayer PPy bending actuator can be considered a DPS. As a consequence the actuator dynamics has been modeled by a linear PDE. Therefore, utilization of these actuators in functional devices requires a proper control strategy which is robust against uncertainty in both the plant and the spatial distribution of the inputs and outputs. In the present study the system uncertainty is due to the variation of the tip mass and the location of the external disturbance load.

sec.title: Problem definition
sec.p: Consider a 2 mm wide, 10 mm long, fast trilayer PPy bending actuator with variable tip mass. In particular, the tip mass varies from 0 to 35.5 mg. Utilizing equation (22) the dynamics of the actuator can be defined as
where

sec.title: Design specification
sec.p: A suitable controller and pre-filter are to be designed having the following properties.
First, the closed-loop system is stable

Second, it can track desired inputs: robust tracking specification based on suitable performance of the actuator is overshoot (=5%) and the settling time (=1 s) for all plant uncertainty. The tracking specification can be defined as

sec.title: Simulation of design
sec.p:
In this section the effectiveness of the designed controller is demonstrated by means of numerical simulations. Figure 11 shows the time-domain simulation for unit step responses. Figure 12 gives the satisfaction of desired tracking specifications in the frequency domain. Since a proper controller must suppress arbitrary disturbances, two different disturbances are used to ensure that the QFT controller has consistent controlling performance. The first case is a step disturbance, fd, and the second one is a sinusoidal disturbance,
f
d
·
e
− t
sin ( 3 π t )
. Five parameters are considered in simulations, namely location of disturbance load, variation of tip loading, response of the controlled system to disturbance load, response of the system without controller to disturbance load, and control effort. Figures 13 to 20 demonstrate the disturbance rejection problem. It is evident that the system performance under the designed controller is robust against variation of the tip loading, location of the external disturbance load, and also the type of disturbance load. Since the actuator is a cantilever, location of the external disturbance load plays an important role in the disturbance attenuation capability of the controller. In the other words, the vibration suppression is more difficult when the disturbance load is located closer to the actuator tip. Comparing Figures 13 and 15 with Figures 17 and 19 demonstrates the robustness of our designed controller against the variation of the disturbance load location. However as anticipated, changing the location of the disturbance load from
x
d
= L
/ L 2
2
to
x
d
= 3 L
/ 3 L 4
4
increases the control effort (Figures 14, 16, 18, and 20). Connecting tip mass decreases the fundamental natural frequency of the actuator, but it is evident from Figures 13 to 20 that the designed controller can robustly control the vibration. Moreover the robust tracking performance is also tested for two different trajectories and variation of tip loading. Figure 21 shows the tracking problem for all considered uncertainty under a sinusoidal reference input, while Figures 22 and 23 depict the tracking error and the control effort. Figure 24 shows the tracking problem for all considered uncertainty under a square wave reference input, while Figures 25 and 26 illustrate the tracking error and the control effort. According to the simulation results, the polymer actuator can consistently track desired inputs despite the variation of tip mass.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper the dynamic modeling and robust control of the fast trilayer PPy bending actuator has been studied. The Euler–Bernoulli beam model with inclusion of tip loading and Kelvin–Voigt damping has been utilized for dynamic modeling of the actuator. Galerkin’s method has been used for solving the dynamic equations. The proposed dynamic model has been validated based on reported experimental data. This model can be used both to optimize the open-loop displacement of the actuator and to design a proper controller, which will lead to practical use of the actuator in micro/nano systems. Considering the fact that the actuator is a DPS, the modified QFT technique has been employed to synthesize a controller which is robust against uncertainty due to spatial distribution of the disturbance load and variation of the tip loading. The simulation results indicate that the performance of the controller is independent of the disturbance load type, the variation of tip loading, and the location of disturbance load, which are necessary conditions for any control system that can successfully suppress arbitrary external disturbances. Finally, robust tracking performance has been demonstrated in tracking different trajectories.

ack.p: This work is a part of a research program for achieving a new generation of actuators that can be used in micro and nano robots. The authors would like to thank the referees for their valuable comments and the second author would like to sincerely thank Mr Amir Hossein Amiri Moghadam from the University of Malaya for his useful comments and valuable suggestions during this work.
